ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: 2.It was difficult without a grounding in either religion or ethnography to understand the vocabulary.4. I think this class had the most reading out of all my classes...especially the last few classes.

I'm a policy person, but a course like this should be required not just so that people understand the reality of the situation of indigenous people better but also so that they become conscious of their own embedded biases.

For Question 10, I think Professor Grim has a lot of understanding and sensitivity to different worldviews, histories and theories, which makes it helpful for non-indigenous peoples to learn important concepts and why it is important to learn them.
the opportunity to discuss the readings, the small group setting, John Grim's excitement about every topic
the extra examples brought in from students and Prof Grim, along with the really good discussion that arose from the lack of fear students had asking questions.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: A few too many readings. (4 books in one semester, plus other associated readings, is a LOT.)

I would have appreciated having a bit more background knowledge, especially in terms of the anthropological theories that were being discussed. Many of the other students in the seminar had either previously worked with indigenous peoples, or were familiar with some branch of anthropology. I frequently felt that the level of discussion was out of my league, especially when students brought in knowledge from their experiences (however edifying these were).
The class can be a bit long and tiring, especially when no bathroom break is given. A break should be kept for next time teaching the class.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: greatly available

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: As I would like to concentrate on environmental issues primarily among impacted indigenous communities it was useful to have a deeper understanding of some communities' religious perspective on the issues.
it provides a social component to policy, and helps me become aware of issues that should be considered when doing anything.

I seek a better understanding of indigenous cultures and rights in my program and this class, especially with discussion of multiple communities and UNDRIP, has allowed me to better understand indigenous cultures and rights to these cultures.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: personal interest.
Needed to open my mind and broaden my way of thinking to avoid becoming stuck in a policy rut.

Coming from a background with little information on indigenous peoples, I mainly wanted to know more about how a people's way of life could theoretically and practically be in harmony with their environment's proceedings.

I really appreciate Grim's understanding, sensitivity, knowledge and teaching style. I also took this class to better achieve the goals set out in my program to better understand indigenous cultures and rights.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes, definitely
It was far more theoretical and abstract than I expected, but nonetheless was an excellent course that I am thankful to have taken.

Yes, I have a much wider understanding of indigenous cultures (I understood only a handful before taking the class) and how indigenous rights laid out in UNDRIP and in traditional law can help protect culture.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes, and more

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings!
Try to keep up with the readings. Though there's a lot, it's pretty interesting. Don't be afraid to ask questions in class and reach out to Prof Grim.
